awd_titl_txt: Community Based Conservancies: Investigating the Prospects for Cooperation and Conflict
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award will investigate the efficacy of community-based approaches to protecting natural resources. Natural resources provide environmental services such as clean water and air, genetic diversity, and employment opportunities. How to best manage these resources remains a challenge because of the many, often competing, demands made on them by different groups. Over the last few decades, methods of conservation have undergone significant change from approaches that prohibited any human use of key areas to those that recognize the important role that user communities have to play. Understanding if and how community-based approaches to conservation work is important for assuring that future efforts at designing policies and programs for natural resource protection and utilization are efficient and effective.

The researcher has chosen to conduct the research in East Africa because she has found a site where some community-based approaches, which are known as Community Based Conservancies or CBCs, have been operating for some time while others are just being introduced. This allows her to carry out a scientifically rigorous comparative project to evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of this approach to natural resource management.  The region is home to important wildlife species such as lion, elephant, rhino, cheetah and giraffe. These animals live in landscapes alongside communities of livestock herders who depend for their livelihoods on the same resources as the wildlife. Thus, this is an ideal setting in which to understand how community-based approaches to conservation work, their costs and benefits to communities, and whether they are an effective and efficient means of resource management. Data will be collected interviews, observations, surveys, experimental economics, and document analysis. These data will allow the team to study the process of CBC formation, community participation, and how land use rules are designed and implemented. They will assess how CBCs affect cooperation and conflict among CBC members as well as communities that are adjacent to but outside of CBCs. The investigators also will construct computer simulation (agent-based) models to understand how changes brought about by CBCs affect the environment and household well-being. The study will provide education and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at two American universities. Study results and the simulation models produced, which will be made publically available, will be applicable to other settings, such as national parks and other key sites in the United States.

por.por_cntn:
Community-based wildlife conservation is presented as a win-win-win proposition in which wildlife and plant biodiversity are conserved for the global community, the state earns revenue from tourism, and communities gain benefits from improved security, tourism and related enterprises. Through in-depth, multi-method anthropological research in three community-based conservancies (CBC) in northern Kenya, this study found that CBCs are complex social institutions with varied impacts within and across  communities. Major findings of the study concern the institutional structure and function of CBCs, the distribution of costs and benefits from CBCs, the implications of CBCs for cooperation and conflict and possible futures of CBCs based on simulation modeling. CBCs represent a new institution for land use with distinctive rules, procedures, resources and governing structures. The study develops the concept of ?institutional layering? to explain how CBCs interface with pre-existing land use institutions such as traditional elders and group ranches. Institutional layering creates governance challenges as roles and responsibilities overlap and often lack clarity, sometimes resulting in conflict over how land should be managed and who has access to range resources. A second important finding from the study is that, contrary to promises of significant economic benefits from conservation, when measured, economic benefits at household level are very limited. Only about 15% of members report receiving any economic benefit and overall, these represent, on average, less than 1.5% of annual income. A small number of community members employed by the CBCs benefit more, but, in general, benefits to households are negligible. Although community members do perceive some benefits from CBCs such as improved security and subsidized school fees, the study reveals that there is a risk that promised benefits will fall short of expectations and may be outweighed by costs such as losing access to grazing land that is set aside for wildlife protection.

Effective community conservation requires a high degree of cooperation and the study found that most CBC members tried to cooperate by, for example, adhering to CBC prohibitions on land use in designated conservation areas. We also found, however, that CBCs contributed to conflict within and among communities. For example, people from outside the CBCs often entered protected areas without permission, thus violating CBC rules and leading to conflicts as CBC members tried to remove them, sometimes forcibly. The relatively large resource flows from donor agencies that support CBCs led to conflicts in the CBC communities as they created widespread suspicion that funds were misused by CBC leadership. Efforts at accountability by CBC boards and staff often fell short, eroding trust and hindering CBC operations. The ongoing formation of CBCs across the northern Kenya landscape, which is meant to protect wildlife and biodiversity, actually appears to create islands of policed territory that may contribute more to land fragmentation and conflict than to harmonious conservation.

The study utilized simulation and agent-based modeling to create scenarios about the long range impacts of CBCs. One model estimated the effects of removing protected areas from grazing access and reducing the distance livestock are able to travel to access grazing. Shorter grazing orbits were associated with lower well-being indicators such as fewer livestock holdings, less income and greater need for relief food. Another model showed that increasing rainfall variability, likely to occur with climate change, resulted in reduced livestock holdings and increased need for relief food. However, reduced access to grazing land, represented by CBCs, had relatively minor impacts compared to those caused by climate variability.

The study has had broader impacts through training field researchers and disseminating findings through publications and discussions. Eighteen Kenyan field researchers received training and experience in multi-method research over the course of the study, improving local research capacity in communities that have few such opportunities. The publication of a book, ?Conservation and Community in Kenya: Milking the Elephant? in 2022 shares the findings of the study with a broad audience and will be used in university courses. Additional publications are in preparation for submission to peer reviewed journals. A website is being developed to share the modeling approach used in the project and to make it publicly available. We have also presented and discussed the findings of the study with the three CBCs that took part. These discussions are ongoing and exploring the practical implications of the findings and how CBCs can use them to improve their operations and engagement with their members.
